s.text: Only 7% of patients managed without drugs used any test strips during the year.
For patients using oral medications, older age and lower neighborhood SES were also associated with lower odds of initiating SMBG.
Furthermore, the structure of the pharmacy benefit at the time of our study makes it very likely that all test strip dispensings would occur in health plan pharmacies.
Our findings suggest that managed care patients who may benefit the most from intensive diabetes management may be least likely to self-monitor blood glucose.
Harvard Vanguard Medical Associates (HVMA) is a multi-specialty group practice serving nearly 300,000 people in diverse ethnic and socioeconomic communities in and around Boston, Massachusetts.
Cut points for regular use were based on dispensing patterns and recent guidelines recommending testing three to four times per day for insulin users and less frequent testing for non-insulin users.
SMBG frequency was well below recommended guidelines for both insulin and sulfonylurea patients (Table 2).
While the efficacy of self-monitoring independent of other self-management practices is still uncertain, the practice is recommended for patients using either insulin or oral drug therapy.
